summary: This is a court filing from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, specifically an appendix volume containing documents related to the civil case against Ghislaine Maxwell. It includes a district court order denying Maxwell's motion to reconsider the unsealing of deposition transcripts, a notice of appeal, a sealed declaration, and a letter from Maxwell's counsel requesting a stay of the unsealing process due to new information in the parallel criminal case. This document contains multiple parts: (1) a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's counsel to Judge Preska regarding the unsealing protocol in the civil case, (2) a protective order from the criminal case against Maxwell, (3) an order from Judge Preska denying Maxwell's request for a stay of unsealing, and (4) transcripts from two hearings (2016 and 2020) in the civil defamation case. The materials center on discovery disputes, protective orders, and the process of unsealing court records. This is a transcript of a court hearing before Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the unsealing of numerous documents in the civil litigation related to Jeffrey Epstein. The hearing details specific docket entries, including depositions of Ghislaine Maxwell and various Jane/John Does, that are to be unsealed, partially unsealed, or remain sealed. The hearing concludes with Maxwell's attorney requesting a stay to appeal the unsealing order to the Second Circuit, citing Maxwell's recent indictment and concerns about a fair trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The central defendant in the civil case; her depositions from April 22, 2016, and other dates are the subject of the unsealing debate. Her attorney argues that her recent criminal indictment changes the calculus for unsealing.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The judge presiding over the civil case in the Southern District of New York, who issued the orders denying reconsideration and setting the unsealing schedule.

persons.name: Sigrid S. McCawley
persons.context: A partner at Boies, Schiller & Flexner LLP representing the plaintiff. She submitted a sealed declaration in support of a motion to exceed deposition limits.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, signs the letter to Judge Preska and appears at the 2016 and 2020 hearings arguing discovery issues and opposing pro hac vice motions.

persons.name: Ty Gee
persons.context: An attorney with Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: An attorney with Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., listed as counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Sharon Churcher
persons.context: Filed a motion to quash a subpoena (docket entry 215), mentioned in the list of motions proposed for unsealing review.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Listed as a respondent in the appellate case caption. The document references criminal investigations into individuals associated with him.

persons.context: Listed as an intervenor in the appellate case caption.

persons.context: Attorney for the plaintiff (Jane Doe) in the civil defamation case. Appears at the 2016 and 2020 hearings, argues for pro hac vice admissions and discovery motions.

persons.context: Another non-party mentioned in the sealed materials. Part of the chronology for unsealing review.

persons.context: Maxwell's attorney who argues against unsealing, requests a stay to appeal to the Second Circuit, and files declarations in support of motions.

persons.name: McCawley
persons.context: Opposing counsel who argues for the material to be unsealed quickly and files declarations in support of motions to compel.

connections.description: Menninger is listed as an attorney representing Maxwell, filing appeals and correspondence on her behalf.
The document references Maxwell as being part of a group of "unknown individuals associated with Jeffrey Epstein" who were under criminal investigation.
They are opposing counsel in the civil case, as evidenced by correspondence and certificate of service documents.
Judge Preska is presiding over Maxwell's civil case and ruling on her motions regarding the sealing of documents.
Both are attorneys representing the plaintiff (Jane Doe). McCawley advocates for Cassell's pro hac vice admission.
Both are attorneys for the plaintiff seeking pro hac vice status. They were co-defendants in related Florida litigation.
Pagliuca is defense counsel for Maxwell, appearing at the 2016 hearing to oppose pro hac vice motions.
Both are defense attorneys for Ghislaine Maxwell, working together on the case.
Cassell seeks to represent the plaintiff suing Maxwell for defamation. Maxwell's counsel opposes his pro hac vice admission.
Correspondence between Maxwell and Epstein from January 2015 is ordered unsealed, indicating a direct communication link.
Menninger is Maxwell's defense attorney, advocating for her interests by seeking stays and opposing unsealing.
Opposing counsel in the litigation, with Menninger representing Maxwell and McCawley likely representing the plaintiff.
Dr. Olsen's deposition mentions Maxwell, and portions concerning her medical history are to remain sealed.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested, as referenced in the court's order noting it occurred three weeks prior to the July 23 decision.

events.title: Court Order to Unseal Depositions
events.description: Judge Preska ordered the unsealing of Maxwell's and Doe 1's deposition transcripts and related materials.

events.title: Denial of Reconsideration and Notice of Appeal
events.description: Judge Preska denied Maxwell's motion for reconsideration of the unsealing order. Maxwell filed a notice of appeal to the Second Circuit.

events.title: Discovery of New Information
events.description: Maxwell's counsel learned of critical new information impacting both the civil and criminal cases, which they claim affects due process and fairness.

events.title: Deposition of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: A deposition transcript of Ghislaine Maxwell from this date is referenced as an exhibit in a sealed declaration.

events.title: Protective Order Issued in Criminal Case
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues a protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330) governing the handling of discovery, including confidential and highly confidential information (e.g., sexualized images).

events.title: Judge Preska Denies Stay of Unsealing
events.description: Judge Loretta A. Preska denies Ghislaine Maxwell's request for a three-week stay of the unsealing process in the civil case, citing lack of a reasonable basis as the information is covered by the criminal protective order.

events.title: Discovery Hearing Before Judge Sweet
events.description: Judge Robert W. Sweet holds a hearing on discovery motions and pro hac vice applications for plaintiff's attorneys Paul Cassell and Brad Edwards. He conditionally denies the pro hac motions pending resolution of related Florida litigation.

events.title: Unsealing Hearing Before Judge Preska
events.description: Judge Loretta A. Preska conducts a remote hearing regarding the unsealing of documents related to Does 1 and 2. She rules that the presumption of public access outweighs countervailing interests and orders the documents unsealed with redactions.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Deposition
events.description: Deposition of Ghislaine Maxwell taken; multiple excerpts from this deposition are the subject of the unsealing order.

events.title: Plaintiff's Deposition
events.description: Deposition of the plaintiff (likely a victim) taken; excerpts are ordered unsealed.

events.title: Maxwell-Epstein Correspondence
events.description: Correspondence between Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein; ordered unsealed in full.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Indictment
events.description: Maxwell's attorney references that Maxwell has been indicted and a trial scheduled for July of the following year, changing the legal context for the unsealing debate.

events.title: Unsealing Hearing
events.description: Court hearing before Judge Nathan to rule on the unsealing of numerous documents in the civil case, resulting in a detailed order.

locations: United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10007
U.S. Virgin Islands (referenced in context of investigations by its Attorney General)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested on July 2, 2020, and indicted, which became a central point in her argument to keep deposition transcripts sealed.
Judge Loretta Preska denied Maxwell's last-minute motion to reconsider the unsealing of her and Doe 1's deposition transcripts, stating the arguments were already considered.

Maxwell's counsel appealed the unsealing order to the Second Circuit and requested a temporary stay, citing new information discovered on August 7, 2020, that is subject to a protective order in the parallel criminal case.

The document references a sealed declaration by plaintiff's attorney Sigrid McCawley that includes exhibits such as a Palm Beach Police Report and a 2005 sworn statement, indicating the use of investigative materials in the civil case.

The parties agreed to some modifications to streamline the unsealing process, including notifying all non-parties at once and shortening objection deadlines, but disagreed on page limits for briefing.

A detailed protective order from July 30, 2020, in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell establishes strict rules for handling discovery, including 'Highly Confidential Information' containing nude or sexualized images.

Judge Preska denies Maxwell's request to stay the civil unsealing process because the 'critical new information' she references is covered by the criminal protective order and cannot be disclosed to the Court.

During a 2016 hearing, Maxwell's counsel opposed pro hac vice admissions for plaintiff's attorneys Paul Cassell and Brad Edwards, arguing they would be witnesses and had conflicts due to related Florida litigation.

Judge Preska, in a July 2020 hearing, orders the unsealing of documents related to Does 1 and 2, finding the public interest outweighs claims of embarrassment or interference with the criminal investigation.
The document references ongoing discovery disputes in the civil case, including requests for the plaintiff's medical records, tax returns, media contracts, and communications with law enforcement.

The hearing transcript details a meticulous, document-by-document review by Judge Nathan of what should be unsealed from the civil litigation docket, with many references to depositions of Ghislaine Maxwell and various Jane/John Does.

Ghislaine Maxwell's attorney reveals she has been criminally indicted and a trial is scheduled for the following July, arguing this new development warrants a stay of unsealing to protect her right to a fair trial.
Specific items ordered unsealed include correspondence between Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein from January 2015.

The judge grants Maxwell's attorney one week to file an emergency motion with the Second Circuit to stay the unsealing, while simultaneously ordering the legal teams to prepare the documents for release.

The document references numerous sealed or redacted items related to non-party victims (Does 1, 2, 3, 4, 67, 84, 131, 151, 162) and medical records, indicating the broad scope of sensitive material in the case.
